A complete bibliography and repository of Sheldon I. Pollock's scholarly work.

Home Search Annotate me

Bibliography by Alex Gil. Works shared by the author, Sheldon I. Pollock. Site built using Ed, a Jekyll theme designed by Alex Gil.

Sheldon I. Pollock.
a complete bibliography

Articles

  1. Pollock, Sheldon I. “Small Philology and Large Philology.” Comparative Studies of South Asia, Africa and the Middle East 38, no. 1 (May 2018): 122–27. https://doi.org/10.1215/1089201x-4390027. | Download PDF.

  2. ———. “Conundrums of Comparison.” KNOW: A Journal on the Formation of Knowledge 1, no. 2 (September 2017): 273–94. https://doi.org/10.1086/693381. | Download PDF.

  3. ———. “The Columbia Global Humanities Project.” Comparative Studies of South Asia, Africa and the Middle East 37, no. 1 (May 2017): 113–16. https://doi.org/10.1215/1089201x-3821345.

  4. ———. “La Filologia Nel Mondo.” Revista Di Filologia e Di Istruzione Classica 145, no. 1 (2017): 221–51. | Download PDF.

  5. ———. “Areas, Disciplines, and the Goals of Inquiry.” The Journal of Asian Studies 75, no. 4 (November 2016): 913–28. https://doi.org/10.1017/S002191181600111X.

  6. ———. “Philology and Freedom.” Philological Encounters 1, no. 1-4 (January 2016): 4–30. https://doi.org/10.1163/24519197-00000012. | Download PDF.

  7. Pollock, Sheldon I., and U. R. Ananthamurthy, trans. by. “State of Nature (Prakriti).” Seminar, no. 666 (2015): 77–82. http://www.india-seminar.com/2015/666/666_u_r_ananthamurthy.htm. Translated from the Kannada in collaboration with U. R. Ananthamurthy. | Download PDF.

  8. Pollock, Sheldon I. “The Alternative Classicism of Classical India.” Seminar, no. 671 (2015). Reprinted with emendations from “Indian Classicity.” | Download PDF.

  9. ———. “Liberating Philology.” Verge 1, no. 1 (2015): 16–21. | Download PDF.

  10. ———. “Rice and Ragi: Remembering URA.” Seminar, no. 666 (2015): 16–20. https://www.india-seminar.com/2015/666/666_sheldon_pollock.htm. | Download PDF.

  11. ———. “Philologia Rediviva?” American Academy of Arts and Sciences Bulletin 68, no. 1 (2015): 34–36. https://www.amacad.org/news/philologia-rediviva. | Download PDF.

  12. ———. “Philology in Three Dimensions.” Postmedieval: a Journal of Medieval Cultural Studies 5, no. 4 (December 2014): 398–413. https://doi.org/10.1057/pmed.2014.33. | Download PDF.

  13. ———. “Kritische Philologie.” Geschichte Der Germanistik, no. 45-46 (2014): 5–12. | Download PDF.

  14. ———. “What Is South Asian Knowledge Good for?” South Asia Institute Papers / Beiträge Des Südasianinstituts, no. 1 (2014). | Download PDF.

  15. ———. “Vyakti and the History of Rasa.” Vimarsha, Journal of the Rasthriya Sanskrit Sansthan, no. 6 (2012): 232–53. Special issue, World Sanskrit Conference. | Download PDF.

  16. ———. “Epicycles of Cathay: Commentary on C. De Pee’s ’Cycles of Cathay.’” Fragments: Interdisciplinary Approaches to the Study of Ancient and Medieval Pasts 2 (2012): 68–75. http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.9772151.0002.005.

  17. ———. “Indian Philology and India’s Philology.” Journal Asiatique 299, no. 1 (2011): 423–42. | Download PDF.

  18. ———. “Crisis in the Classics.” Social Research: An International Quarterly 78, no. 1 (2011): 21–48. https://muse.jhu.edu/article/528113/summary. Also in book form, New Delhi: Rupa, 2012: 20-46; Tamil translation: Manarkeni. June, 2012: 47-56. | Download PDF.

  19. ———. “Future Philology? The Fate of a Soft Science in a Hard World.” Critical Inquiry 35, no. 4 (January 2009): 931–61. https://doi.org/10.1086/599594. | Download PDF.

  20. ———. “Towards a Political Philology: D. D. Kosambi and Sanskrit” 43 (July 2008): 52–59. Revised version in D. D. Kosambi: Unsettling the Past, ed. Meera Kosambi. Delhi: Permanent Black, 2013. | Download PDF.

  21. ———. “Is There an Indian Intellectual History?” Journal of Indian Philosophy 36, no. 5-6 (2008): 533–42. | Download PDF.

  22. ———. “The Real Classical Languages Debate.” The Hindu, November 2008. | Download PDF.

  23. ———. “We Need to Find What We Are Not Looking For.” International Association of Asian Studies Newsletter (Leiden) 43, no. Spring (2007): 1, 4–5. | Download PDF.

  24. ———. “Pretextures of Time.” History and Theory, no. 46 (October 2007): 364–81. | Download PDF.

  25. ———. “Sanskrit Knowledge on the Eve of Colonialism and at the Dawn of Globalization.” Tattvabodha: Journal of the National Manuscripts Mission, New Delhi, no. 1 (2006): 29–47. | Download PDF.

  26. ———. “Forms of Knowledge in Early Modern South Asia: Introduction.” Comparative Studies of South Asia, Africa and the Middle East 24, no. 2 (2004): 19–21. https://muse.jhu.edu/article/181659. | Download PDF.

  27. ———. “The Meaning of Dharma and the Relationship of the Two Mīmāṃsās: Appayya Dīkṣita’s ‘Discourse on the Refutation of a Unified Knowledge-System of Pūrvamīmāṃsā and Uttaramīmāṃsā.” Journal of Indian Philosophy, no. 32 (2004): 769–811. Special issue, Dharma, ed. Patrick Olivelle. Reprinted in book form Delhi 2010. | Download PDF.

  28. ———. “Introduction: Working Papers on Sanskrit Knowledge-Systems on the Eve of Colonialism.” Journal of Indian Philosophy 30, no. 5 (2002): 431–39. | Download PDF.

  29. ———. “The New Intellectuals in Seventeenth-Century India.” Indian Economic and Social History Review 38, no. 1 (2001): 3–31. Reprinted in Medieval Mentality, ed. Eugenia Vanina and D. N. Jha. Delhi: Tulika, 2009. | Download PDF.

  30. ———. “The Death of Sanskrit.” Comparative Studies in Society and History 43, no. 2 (2001): 392–426. | Download PDF.

  31. ———. “The Social Aesthetic And Sanskrit Literary Theory.” Journal of Indian Philosophy 29, no. 1/2 (2001): 197–229. https://www.jstor.org/stable/23496871. Reprinted in Abhinavagupta: Reconsiderations, ed. Makarand Paranjape and Sunthar Visuvalingam. New Delhi: Samvad India Foundation, 2005. | Download PDF.

  32. Pollock, Sheldon I., and Carol Appadurai Breckenridge. “In Honor of D. R. Nagaraj.” Public Culture 12, no. 3 (September 2000): xiv–xiv. https://muse.jhu.edu/article/26219. | Download PDF.

  33. Pollock, Sheldon I. “Cosmopolitan and Vernacular in History.” Public Culture 12, no. 3 (September 2000): 591–625. https://muse.jhu.edu/article/26221. | Download PDF.

  34. ———. “The Cosmopolitan Vernacular.” Journal of Asian Studies 57, no. 1 (1998): 6–37. | Download PDF.

  35. ———. “Bhoja’s Śṛṅgāraprakāśa and the Problem of Rasa: A Historical Introduction and Translation.” Asiatische Studien/Études Asiatiques 70, no. 1 (1998): 117–92. | Download PDF.

  36. ———. “India in the Vernacular Millennium: Literary Culture and Polity, 1000-1500.” Edited by S. N. Eisenstadt, Wolfgang Schluchter, and Björn Wittrock. Daedalus 127, no. 3 (1998): 41–74. Special issue, Early Modernities: Varieties and Transitions, ed. S. N. Eisenstadt, Wolfgang Schluchter, and Björn Wittrock. | Download PDF.

  37. Pollock, Sheldon I., and Nalini Balbir. “Genres Littéraires En Inde.” Journal of the American Oriental Society 115, no. 4 (October 1995): 685. https://doi.org/10.2307/604737. | Download PDF.

  38. Pollock, Sheldon I. “Literary History, Region, and Nation in South Asia: Introductory Note.” Social Scientist 23, no. 10-12 (1995): 1–7.

  39. ———. “Literary History, Indian History, World History.” Social Scientist 23, no. 10-12 (1995): 112–42. | Download PDF.

  40. ———. “Public Poetry in Sanskrit.” Indian Horizons 44, no. 4 (1995): 84–106. Special issue, Sanskrit Literature, ed. A. N. D. Haksar. | Download PDF.

  41. ———. “Rāmāyaṇa and Political Imagination in India.” Journal of Asian Studies 52, no. 2 (1993): 261–97. Corrected reprint in Debates in History, ed. David N. Lorenzen. Delhi: Oxford U. Press, 2004. | Download PDF.

  42. ———. “Humanities in South Asian Studies.” Items: Social Science Research Council 44, no. 4 (1990): 81–82.

  43. ———. “From Discourse of Ritual to Discourse of Power in Sanskrit Culture.” Journal of Ritual Studies 4, no. 2 (1990): 315–45.

  44. ———. “Mīmāṃsā and the Problem of History in Traditional India.” Journal of the American Oriental Society 109, no. 4 (1989): 603–11. | Download PDF.

  45. ———. “Ideologia y Narrativa En El Ramayana De Valmiki.” Estudios De Asia y Africa, no. 22 (1987): 336–54.

  46. ———. “The Theory of Practice and the Practice of Theory in Indian Intellectual History.” Journal of the American Oriental Society, no. 105 (1985): 499–519. | Download PDF.

  47. ———. “Rāma’s Madness.” Wiener Zeitschrift Für Die Kunde Südasiens, no. 29 (1985): 43–56.

  48. ———. “Rākṣasas and Others.” Indologica Taurinensia, Journal of the International Association of Sanskrit Studies, no. 13 (1985): 263–81. | Download PDF.

  49. ———. “Daniel H. H. Ingalls.” Journal of the American Oriental Society, no. 105 (1985): 387–89. | Download PDF.

  50. ———. “The Divine King in the Indian Epic.” Journal of the American Oriental Society, no. 104 (1984): 505–28. | Download PDF.

  51. ———. “Ātmānaṃ Mānuṣam Manye: Dharmākūtam on the Divinity of Rāma.” Journal of the Oriental Institute, Baroda, no. 33 (1984): 231–43. | Download PDF.

  52. ———. “Some Lexical Problems in Vālmīki Rāmāyaṇa.” Rtam: Journal of Akhila Bharatiya Sanskrit Parishad XI-XV (1983): 271–88. B. R. Saxsena Special Volume.

  53. Cloud, Random. “The Marriage of Good and Bad Quartos.” Shakespeare Quarterly 33, no. 4 (1982): 421–31. https://doi.org/10.2307/2870123. | Download PDF.
